Leak:
> **Q: When I compile, the window closes mere seconds after opening AND/OR there is red text at the bottom of the window which reads `LoadPortals: couldn't read [MAP_PATH]`, what does this mean?**

**A:** Most likely your map is leaking and as is stated in the channel description of #help-mapping, no, we won't help you with your leak as due to their nature, it's up to the map creator to fix it themselves.
More information on what a 'leak' is and how to fix it can be found on the **Valve Developer Community**.

buildcubemaps Crash:
> **Q: When I try running `buildcubemaps` the game crashes, how do I stop this?**

**A:** Instead of running your maps from `common/Portal 2/portal2/maps`, where they are normally compiled to, open Hammer's settings and set the `Place compiled maps in this directory` option in `Build Programs` to `.\Portal 2\portal2_dlcX\maps`, where `X` is the highest present dlc folder (for most players this will be `dlc2`)

Packing:
> **Q: When I upload a map to the Workshop, people complain of 'purple and black checkerboard textures' (<:twp_missing:263076476268707840>)  or 'ERROR models' (<:twp_error:263125752583684114>), but it appears fine on my end, what is happening?**

**A:** Most likely you are not packing custom assets. When you use an asset—whether it be a texture, prop, script or something else—which does __not__ come with Portal 2, you'll have to 'pack' them into your map. The easiest method is to let **TeamSpen's Hammer Addons** to automatically do it for you at compile time. [https://github.com/teamspen210/hammeraddons/releases]
However, setting up this addon can be somewhat convoluted. If you are having trouble, don't hesitate to ask in #help-mapping or the related FAQ post below.
There may be times TeamSpen's addons may not be able to pack assets automatically, although these are rare. In such situations, it is recommend you use **VIDE**'s Pakfile Lump Editor. [http://www.riintouge.com/VIDE/]
Packable Assets:
> **Q: What types of assets can be packed?**

**A:** The following assets __can__ be packed:
> • Textures
> • Models
> • Music
> • Vscripts
> • Soundscripts
> • Particles
The following assets __can not__ be packed:
> • Bink Videos
> • Custom DLLs
> • Maps
> • `scenes.image`
Decompile Maps:
> **Q: How do I decompile maps? (.bsp files)**

**A:** Decompiling maps is something you should consider doing only for educational purposes, for example, like learning how certain I/O are structured, or how certain parts of a map where bulit etc, on vanilla Portal 2 maps, you are mostly free to do anything you want. VTF Green Tint:
> **Q. My custom textures are getting green-tinted when I import them through VTFEdit. How do I fix it?**

**A.** The simplest solution is to download VTFEdit Reloaded. It fixes the green tint issue and includes some tweaks and upgrades to the vanilla VTFEdit:
[<https://www.mediafire.com/file/gsdik14d9kqa7eh/VTFEditInstaller.msi/file>]
Alternatively, a more "manual" solution for the vanilla tool in the next answer:

**A.** Add a solid color layer on top of your texture, with the color `3, 7, 3` (or `#030703`), set to the "Color Burn" blending mode. While not a perfect fix, it does offset the green tint enough that it looks mostly imperceptible in the final import.
Skybox:
> **Q. My skybox texture doesn't work. How do I fix it?**

**A.** Portal 2 doesn't have support for the `Sky` shader. Instead, what you'll need to do is set your texture's shader to `UnlitGeneric`. Make sure to also remove the `$ignorez 1` parameter (if you had it in the first place). All your skybox texture really needs is the following for its VMT files:
```
"UnlitGeneric"
{
    "$basetexture" "skybox/YOUR_TEXTURE_NAME_HERE"
}
```

As for the VTF files, no special configuration is needed, though setting up the `Clamp S` and `Clamp T` flags (or `Clamp` and `Clamp T` if you use VTFEdit Reloaded) is recommended.
Ask Good Questions:
We are here to _help_, but you must make an active attempt to _try_.
**Modified excerpt(s) from How to Ask Questions the Smart Way:**
>>> It's OK to be ignorant; it's not OK to play stupid.

Before asking a technical question by e-mail, or in a newsgroup, or on a website chat board, do the following:
1. Try to find an answer by searching the archives of [this server].
2. Try to find an answer by searching the Web.
3. Try to find an answer by reading the [Valve Developer Community Wiki].
4. Try to find an answer by reading [the] FAQ.
5. Try to find an answer by inspection or experimentation.
6. Try to find an answer by asking a skilled friend.

When you ask your question, display the fact that you have done these things first; this will help establish that you're not being a lazy sponge and wasting people's time. Better yet, display what you have learned from doing these things. We like answering questions for people who have demonstrated they can learn from the answers.

Take your time. Do not expect to be able to solve a complicated problem with a few seconds of Googling. Read and understand the FAQs, sit back, relax and give the problem some thought before approaching experts. Trust us, they will be able to tell from your questions how much reading and thinking you did, and will be more willing to help if you come prepared. Don't instantly fire your whole arsenal of questions just because your first search turned up no answers (or too many).
